title: 106_s614
content: The Act may be cited as the "Indian Tribal Regulatory Reform and Business Development Act of 2000". Congress acknowledges the challenges faced by Native Americans despite their rich cultural heritage and available resources on Indian lands. These challenges include high rates of unemployment, poverty, poor health, and substandard housing. The capacity of Indian tribes to develop strong governments and economies is hindered by limited engagement with surrounding communities and outside investors. Since 1970, each President has recognized the need for special government-to-government relationships in Indian Affairs. The United States has an obligation to assist Indian tribes with creating economic and political conditions on Indian lands to encourage outside investment and facilitate economic development. The purposes of this Act include reviewing laws affecting investment on Indian lands and determining if they impair business development or financial stability. The Act aims to review laws impacting investment on Indian lands to assess their effect on business development and financial stability. It also seeks to establish an authority to conduct the review and report findings to Congress and the President. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Authority" refers to the Regulatory Reform and Business Development on Indian Lands Authority. "Federal agency" means an agency as defined in title 5, United States Code. "Indian" is defined as per the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. "Indian lands" include lands under the definitions of "Indian country" and "reservation." Section 3(d) of the Indian Financing Act of 1974 and section 4(10) of the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 are referenced. Former Indian reservations in Oklahoma are defined as lands within the jurisdictional areas of an Oklahoma Indian tribe and recognized by the Secretary of the Interior as eligible for trust land status. The term "Indian tribe" is defined as per the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Commerce. The term "tribal organization" is defined in the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. SEC. 4. ESTABLISHMENT OF AUTHORITY. The Regulatory Reform and Business Development on Indian Lands Authority was established by the Secretary to remove obstacles to investment and business development in Native American communities. The Authority consists of 21 members, with 12 representatives from Indian tribes. The Regulatory Reform and Business Development on Indian Lands Authority consists of 21 members, including 12 representatives from Indian tribes and at least 4 members from the private sector. The Authority must hold its initial meeting within 90 days of enactment and conduct reviews of laws affecting investment on Indian lands. Meetings will be called by the chairperson. The Authority consists of 21 members, with 12 from Indian tribes and 4 from the private sector. Meetings are called by the chairperson, who is selected from among the members. A majority of members form a quorum for meetings. The Authority, composed of 21 members, including representatives from Indian tribes and the private sector, will prepare a report within 1 year of the Act's enactment. The report will include findings from a review and recommendations for revisions to laws. The Authority is granted powers outlined in section 6. The Authority, consisting of 21 members, will conduct hearings, gather information from federal agencies, utilize postal services, and accept gifts. Additionally, the Authority will address personnel matters as outlined in section 7. The Authority members serve without compensation, except for travel expenses. Officers and employees of the federal government also serve without additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, are allowed at authorized rates. The chairperson may appoint staff. The chairperson of the Authority has the authority to appoint and terminate necessary personnel without following civil service laws. They can also procure temporary services at specified rates. The Authority will terminate 90 days after submitting the report to Congress and Indian tribes. Its activities are exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Appropriations are authorized as needed.
